msgSnippet: Erik, Have you looked into Mike Clark s JUnitPerf? http://www.clarkware.com/software/JUnitPerf.html Andy.
messageBody:
Erik,

Have you looked into Mike Clark's JUnitPerf?
http://www.clarkware.com/software/JUnitPerf.html

Andy.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Erik Mattsson [mailto:erik.mattsson@...]
> Sent: 18 February 2003 09:22
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] How to test threaded classes?
>
>
> Im having trouble doing unittesting on my threaded classes.
> Background: Ive created a very simple HotFolder class that
> runs in its own thread and notifies listeners every time it
> finds a new file in a folder (path/dir). The class has a few
> public methods, such as start/stop/setFolder/setFilter, the
> rest are private. How do I test this class the best way?
>
> Ive implemented some testcases that uses this hotfolder
> thread that starts the thread and creates files in the active
> folder. Then I check how many times the testcase was notified
> and compares it to the number of actual files created. But
> this fails sometimes, since the computer can be occupied with
> other stuff which delays the hotfolder notifying and
> therefore doesnt report that many new files that I was expecting.
>
> This is a common problem I have with other threads, such as a
> ThumbnailLoader (singleton instance that loads jpeg thumbnails)....
>
>
> So which way is the best to test threaded classes?
> Or is this impossible and should be avoided, and for example
> put the thread stuff into its own class. (But how do you test
> that class :)?
>
>
> I want to have a complete threaded object and not having to
> put the object into as a Runnable every time I want to use
> it. (besides there so much more work to start/stop threads
> that I want to hide in the mentioned class)
>
> Any suggestions?
>
> //erik
